2.text: Confusingly, we speak of love as one thing,

6.text: rather than discerning the 2 very different varieties that lie beneath the single word.

13.text: We can only make a relationship work when we're ready to do the latter

17.text: and are aware of our unnatural, immature fixation on the former.

23.text: We start knowing only about being loved.

25.text: It comes to seem, very wrongly, like the norm.

28.text: To the child it feels as if the parent is simply spontaneously on hand:

32.text: to comfort, guide, tame, feed, clear up, and will remain almost always warm and cheerful.

38.text: Parents don't reveal how often they've bitten their tongue, fought back the tears,

42.text: and been too tired to take off their clothes after a day of child care.

45.text: The relationship is almost always entirely non-reciprocal,

48.text: the parent loves but they don't expect the favor to be returned in any significant way:

53.text: the parent doesn't get upset when the child doesn't notice the new haircut,

57.text: asks carefully calibrated questions about how the meeting at work went, or suggests that they go upstairs and take a nap.

63.text: Parent and child may both love, but each party is on a very different end of the axis, unbeknownst to the child.

70.text: This is why adulthood, when we first say we "long for love",

73.text: what we predominantly mean is that we want to be loved as we are once loved by a parent.

78.text: We want a recreation in adulthood of what it felt like to be administered to and indulged.

83.text: In a secret part of our minds, we picture someone who will understand our needs, bring us what we want,

88.text: to be immensely patient and sympathetic to us, act selflessly, and make it all better.

93.text: This is, naturally, a disaster; for any relationship to work

97.text: we need to move firmly out of the child and into the parental position.

101.text: We need to become someone who can sometimes

103.text: subordinate their own demands to the needs of another.

106.text: To be adults in love, we have to learn, perhaps for the very first time,

110.text: to do something truly remarkable, for a time at least, to put someone else ahead of us.

115.text: That's what true, mature love actually is, much to everyone's initial surprise.
